content.description: Great compression moves on a seductive feature. Begin low, at a sloper in a horizontal seam. Squeeze the rippled left wall and big slopers out right, finishing on vertical rock with a couple long reaches. Be careful what you grab while topping out. This would be a popular classic if not for the large, pointy boulder in the landing and some poor rock up high.
content.protection: A minimum of two pads and an active spotter. An additional small pad or carpet is nice for the start.
content.location: In the middle of the Trailer Park is a steep wall cleaved by a wide gash. Hot Carl climbs the roof on the left side. This problem climbs the steep prow on the right, avoiding features on the left wall of the gash.

content.description: Start on low rail on right side of boulder and go straight up or veer right.
content.location: After getting off main trail, it is on the boulder across the way. Starts on rail on right side of Boulder.

content.description: A nice lock or two along the overhanging fingercrack followed by an exciting, wandering, slopey and dirty highball topout(but easy). An obvious line that required an ascent. Recommended for the purist.
content.location: Left at the bottom of the trail. On the long wall with undercut river rock landing. The most obvious line up the fingercrack. Left of center in the BETA PHOTO for the Trailer Park.

content.description: Right facing corner, starts with hands and fists, a nice rail to crank on then nice fingers with big feet to the top. Fun mellow romp.
content.location: Right facing corner in between planet terror and Godwin direct.

content.description: Work through the overhanging ring locks/tight hands and pull through the roof. Set off into a hands/fists crack that also doubles as a never ending pit of dirt and leaves. Fist/arm bar/chimney your way through the lichen and wide section to the salvation of tight hands to finish strong.
content.protection: Pads. Spotter. There is a big boulder in the landing zone though. I started this with neither and half way up asked my partner to bring pads over. I asked if the pads were in place and he replied “don’t fall”
content.location: Right of the unnamed prow and left of planet terror.

content.description: The short arete that beckons from the approach trail. Begin at a large triangular sloper and follow the arete to a sorta-big reach for the lip. Top out on slick rippled crimps. Feels super stout without good beta.
content.location: Left side of the semi-freestanding boulder. Walk off the back.

content.description: This problem is on the steepest part of the big wall in the Trailer Park. Pull on at low sidepulls and climb past a wide edge and a tiny, painful undercling to reach a right-facing crimp in the roof. Pop for a good hold over the lip, then campus a couple of moves and top out on dirty holds.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a spot for the swing.
content.location: On the steep part of the big wall in the Trailer Park, look for the gaston dishes and climb up and left.

content.description: Improbable and highly technical (in the best way.) Start on a good right-facing hold around waist height and head straight up, using a big and very sloping undercling to reach somewhat hidden holds up high. Finish with a trademark mantel. Good footwork and body English are essential.
content.protection: The landing is pretty good, though a bit tilted. Blowing the mantel can be hairy.
content.location: Turn right from the Trailer Park and walk a few dozen yards down the canyon to a wall on the left. This problem is in the center.

content.description: Start on obvious sloppy rail in the middle of the large roof and climb up and right on the sloppy slot holds to a good crimp.  make a move to a "tooth" hold and topout on the huge shelf.  carefully scoot along the shelf and exit right.  trying to topout straight up is not advised.  Very tall and Very dirty on Very questionable holds.
content.location: Middle of large roof to the left as you enter the canyon.

content.description: Start on Hot Karl, and take a hard left out of the overhang via the pinch/crimp-pocket hold (<<--you'll likely match this hold, or bury your right hand in the crimp-pocket). From here make a big leftward move to a decent, but sloping, left-handed gaston, and toe down to fish your right hand out over the lip to more slopers. Then, get set up and figure out how to heave your body upwards toward the top-out jug. The crimp seam is surprisingly bad and the finishing jug feels like it's miles away. If you feel like you're wrestling a grizzly bear you're on the right path. A really fun problem that's on par with the classic hard moderates in the canyon.
content.location: The Hot Karl prow in the Trailer Park Area.

content.description: Fine pocket pulling on a gently overhanging face. Begin at sloping underclings and head for the good horizontal. Drop off, or top it out if you're into choss, dirt, and unnecessary danger.
content.protection: Pad or two and a spot.
content.location: On the big wall on the left side of the Trailer Park, near the left side.

content.description: vimeo.com/6833027
content.location: To the right of hot carl in the corner.

content.description: Like the arete to the left, this problem is a classic, even though it's short. Start both hands underclinging the left angling crack. Move left to a layback dish along the crack. From here, put together a beautiful sequence of laid back moves including delicate footwork on perfect features, a sloper, an edge, and a final lunge to a jug at the top of the block.
content.protection: One or two pads will do it.
content.location: On the "sometimes sunny" boulder facing the bottom of the trail, to the right of the Triangle Arete(what I call Sometimes Sunny). Follows features along the crack.

content.description: Pull on with crimpy underclings and head for the slopey ledge out left. Bust right toward the horizontal, then drop off, or top out if you're in the mood for a faceful of moss and dirt. Fingery.
content.location: Left wall in the Trailer Park, this is the furthest left problem through the nice small edges.

content.description: Big moves out of a roof on a free standing boulder past the left boulder in the Beta photo.  Kind of sketchy landing.  Put up by Carlito (Dr) Goff back in the early days of Kelly Canyon.
content.protection: Crash Pad or two with a good spot

content.description: Start at the skirt and climb easily to the bulge, which is covered with bad slopers. Figure out a way to grovel over the top.
content.location: This problem is visible just up canyon from the Trailer Park, on the same wall as The Impossible Undercling, to the left of that problem.

content.description: Fingery and technical. Begin with the good right hand "hole" at the bottom of the scoop. Climb out the scoop to a bad horizontal edge/pinch, then right through shallow seams. Stick the big horizontal and drop off or do the awful, dirty topout. Taller climbers will have a significant advantage.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spot.
content.location: On the tall wall on the left side of the Trailer Park, this is the scoop left of the big roof and crack problem.

content.description: Start at a large undercling and make long moves past friendly holds. A nice contrast to the more technical right arete.
content.protection: Pad and spotter, the landing is decent.
content.location: Upon entering the Trailer Park, this problem is directly to the left. The topout puts you back on the trail.

content.description: Sit start with very low holds and go straight up past an intriguing flat sloper into the sandy horizontal. The topout has some hidden holds. Crack to the right is off.
content.location: On the far left side of the Aloha boulder (the first one reached in the Trailer Park.)

content.description: Start with crimps and make a couple tricky moves to the excellent sloper rails on the arete, then onward to a gravy finish. Smart footwork and body position are essential.
content.location: Upon entering the Trailer Park, this is on the wall directly to the left and is very obvious. The topout puts you back on the trail.

content.description:
This is the first area reached from the trail. Lots of good stuff here. One of the first areas in the canyon to dry out, though the scooped wall at left typically overhangs a sizable pool late into the spring.  

  Problems are sorted counter-clockwise, beginning at the bottom of the trail.
